text: Family Member: I’m like, wow. Patient: My, gosh. We was in Langa, and then Langa- Doctor: So did, was that part of the tour to see that or that was just you could not see that in just where you were going? Patient: Everything was part of the tour. Yeah. Family Member: Um hum. It’s all included. Patient: Everything is, and then you have some passages- Doctor: I mean, like the poor areas of the country, that was part of the tour, or you just look out the window and that’s what you see? Patient: When, when we went to Langa, that was, that was different than where they was going. So we, we, they had a package to go to Langa. We went to- Doctor: What’s Langa? Patient: Langa is a little town. Family Member: It’s a little town outside of Cape Town. Patient: Right.

text: Family Member: He didn’t care. Doctor: Multiple. Healthcare Professional: Excuse me. He did have labs done. Doctor: Yeah. He told me that. So the PSA is what? Healthcare Professional: Sixty. Doctor: Sixty? So here it’s sixty point four. (Sound Door closes) Patient: No. I want it. I want to get it over with. Doctor: Okay. (Laughter) Family Member: Right. Patient: The longer I wait, the more things break on me. You know what I mean? Doctor: Well. Family Member: Yeah, because we have a whole schedule of appointments. Doctor: Okay. So when are his, uh, eye surgeries scheduled?

text: Patient: Okay. So (clears throat) Doctor: Uh usually they’ve told us a turn-around of one week after they get it Patient: Okay. Doctor: so I would say by a couple of weeks we should know. Doctor: Now for this study you have to come back within ten days or so from today to get uh do the endo study stuff. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So I was hoping at that point if we have some answers for you we can even get… Family Member: Mm, even get started. Doctor: … start anticipating and making some decisions about the other thing. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Patient: That’ll work. Doctor: So I was gonna say you should sign the pre-screening consent if that’s okay with you and send the blood test out.

text: Patient: And my PSA wasn’t on the sheet. Do you guys have a number on that? Doctor: It’s not back. Did you do it yesterday? No today. Patient: We did labs today. Doctor: Oh, okay. Family Member: Next Friday we’ll be back to plan out the next step and… Doctor: That’s what I’m thinking. Family Member: The tests should be back by then? Doctor: Yeah, but you know what just for now wait for a phone call and I’ll have S call you as soon as we get the results so we can sort of plan better for that Friday. Family Member: So it’s just a one day in and out thing? Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Show me how is the shoulder doing? Patient: Oh the shoulders are good.

text: Patient: Okay. Is that the – Doctor: Xtandi. Patient: Xtandi. Okay. That was a shot once a month or? Doctor: That was the pills you were taking. Patient: Oh, I did take them. Yeah. Okay. Doctor: So that would say if we did that just as a course of action and the likelihood it’s gonna help you is pretty low. Patient: Oh. Doctor: And so, this study is looking at a new therapy –uh, the hottest new drugs that are out there, and when we’ve given them to men with prostate cancer, we haven’t seen a whole lot. (Pause) Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Um. And the two drugs together, uh, may be, uh, cause responses. Uh, but we don’t know. And that’s why we’re doing a research study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we’re giving folks who’ve got bad disease this because the worry is these drugs may have a lot of side effects. Most of the time, they’re tolerated well, but what they do is they turn on your immune system, hope that your immune system is going to attack your cancer, but I also could turn on your immune system with these medicines and it attacks you. Okay? So you can get a pneumonia that’s from your immune system. You can get hepatitis because it’s attacking your liver. You could get colitis ‘cuz it’s attacking your colon. Uh, it usually picks one organ, not not all of ‘em, but, you know, you can get into trouble because your immune system – while it’s tryin’ to fight your cancer, it’s tryin’ to fight you. Uh. And when we Patient: I see. This is from the – both the uh– the, uh, both of the –

text: Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Number two, can we do additional molecular testing that you and I talked about early on… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …which you know we use a company called Caris. Patient: Right. Doctor: uh Molecular Intelligence. There are many. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: But here once we send it they bill your insurance. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Then we get the report back and we’re up to about eight hundred genes that they look at. And some of that actually is important for us because it sometimes can direct what we do whether it’s a trial for now or later and also gets us a sense of what that cancer looks like blueprinted. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Which you know it’s a different blueprint than what you were born with. Patient: Yes.

text: Family Member: So back here next Thursday or Friday? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah I was thinking Friday might be a little bit safer just to be on the safe side. Next Friday. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: The other way we could do it is we could do two weeks from today, but uh then the end of treatment stuff that S needs to do for this particular study since we’re stopping this study, that needs to happen within ten days from now. text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And to be together. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So everything we’ve done so far is to try to keep the ball away from the glove. (Beeping) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The cancer sometimes will evolve a form of the glove that doesn’t need a ball. It, it still works. Patient: I see. Doctor: All the things it does downstream without the ball. We’ve been testing that as part of this trial. So I need to dig into the group that’s testing and find out are you one of those guys that was positive? Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you were positive, that would mean pretty strongly that we shouldn’t try more hormone treatments. You need to be positive for that to go on this immune trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh they’re looking for folks who might have more aggressive hormone insensitive cases. So I’m, I’m going to do that this week just to find out.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s a question of taking two pills versus one pill. Okay. There’s a forty percent chance that the coin will flip coin will flip in that direction and you will be selected to take only the Xtandi. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And there’s a sixty percent chance that the coin will flip and you will get selected to receive the combination, the FDA approved drug plus the experimental drug. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: This is not a drug that even if I really wanted you to get on this group, I could just prescribe. Because not been FDA approved for any cancer type, um certainly not for prostate cancer. Um, but the thing that I always want people to understand, when it comes to this clinical trial is, that if you decide you you want to participate in it, you need to conscious of both scenarios. In other words, if you know in your heart of heart-heart’s that you’re going to drop out if you don’t need the new drug (beeper sounds) Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Then please let me know and we will not do this with you, just give you the routine treatment. Okay. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So, I just wanted to s-stop there at the moment and I want to give you this piece of paper so you can look at it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um and do you have any questions about any of that because I know it can be quite complicated and uh information. Doctor: Exactly. The the good thing about this trial I did not mention, I think I should, um there’s no placebo involved. So there are some studies where they give people um a sugar pill or basically inactive medication. This trial does not involve a placebo. And also in this trial, in both groups, both of you get the Xtandi by itself or the Xtandi plus the new experimental drug active therapy.

text: Patient: Berries and <____>. Doctor: High fiber, low fat? Patient: Yes. As much as I can. Doctor: And you’re in good shape where you don’t have a big belly or anything like that. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So that’s good. Patient: And so the likelihood of what you’re seeing reoccurring is is is it high, minimum? Doctor: I would say, I would say based on so far minimum. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And if we go a year and find it’s still undetectable, uh then I think that uh that chances are very good that if it does reoccur that we can control it. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: I would say if it goes beyond a year I would say the risk is minimal and it continues to decrease.

text: Patient: Overall, I’m feeling pretty good. Doctor: Did she grill you? Patient: Yes. She did. Doctor: Okay. Well, what are your thoughts on that horrible chemo word? Patient: You know, I’d always like, like to think it was an option of last resort but apparently we’re there. Doctor: It’s not a last resort. It’s an option. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You just have never, everything you’ve had is all pill, pill, pill, pill, and your body’s figured it out, so. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We’ve got a, we’ve got to try to kill the cells another way. Patient: Sneak up on it another way. Uh. Doctor: Pretty much. Speaking of which, Dr. C___ says hi.

text: Patient: Don’t go there. I’m trying to ask a good question – Doctor: Okay. Patient: - that I’m trying to feel and understand and I know you have an answer as to if that’s going down, why am I feeling this pain again? Has the chemo kind of lessened up again that’s why we need a second and a third one to really go after them? Doctor: Yeah. Well it’s not lessened up, it’s just this does not do anything. This is a nice false sense of like hmm it’s going in the right direction. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But you have plenty more cells we got to kill. Patient: Yeah, yeah, okay. Doctor: So that’s one. Normally it takes three to sometimes four doses… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …for it to work and that’s true for most medicines. It takes three to four doses of anything for anything to work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You don’t have enough in your blood stream to do anything.

text: Patient: We have my father-in-law, Dr. ____ on the phone. Doctor: Okay, hi R____. Family Member: Hi, good morning. Doctor: Yeah, so uh, uh, I think you met them all before. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: and so welcome back, unfortunately. (chuckles) Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So you uh, we went through uh the you know clinical trial and you went to surgery, and uh when they did the surgery uh you had some lymph nodes uh that popped up, and we uh wanted to get a better sense of using the special PSMA scan, uh what was going on, where there was cancer left. And so we had to do the scan, and uh the good news is we found prostate cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, and uh the bad news is we found prostate cancer, but we sort of knew it was there. Patient: Right. Doctor: And and what we saw on the scan basically is in your pelvis here, from here down to where the prostate was there’s still a lot of lymph nodes with prostate cancer in them. The good news is we didn’t see any higher; so it sort of ends at the pelvis, and we didn’t see any in the bones.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: The good news is just so you hear it, is half the guys are cured at five years and then if you look ten years down – Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: - the line, nine out of ten guys are still alive if you go through the hormones and surgery, hormones and radiation, okay. Patient: Sure, uh hum. Doctor: You may be fighting prostate cancer, but you’re alive. Family Member: Right. Patient: Right, right, yeah. Doctor: So, so I just want to take a moment and pause and say we’ve got a serious problem here but it’s not a death sentence a year from now or two years from now. Patient: Right, right, right. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Perspective.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
